blah_1977 wrote:
> Hello,
>     I was browsing the API for CrawlURIDispositionListener, and I came
> upon this little blurb:
> 
>  * Also note that the object implementing this interface
>  * must under <b>no circumstances</b> maintain a reference
>  * to the CrawlURI beyond the scope of the relevant method
>  * body!
> 
> What will happen if a class implementing this interface DOES
> temporarily maintain a reference to the CrawlURIs received through the
> interface?  Will it be OK if the references to the CrawlURIs are
> released and available for GC eventually?  (e.g., store the CrawlURIs
> in a set for processing after crawl completion, after which the set is
> emptied, freeing up all references to the CrawlURIs)

The comment may be a little strong, but the problem is that once 
the CrawlURI completes its processing cycle, almost all its 
interesting state is discarded. (See CrawlURI.stripToMinimal() and 
CrawlURI.processingCleanup().)

So especially if you were hoping to do any additional analysis in 
another thread, the info could be yanked out from under you.

I suggest you copy what you need at the moment the CrawlURI is 
passed with the notification, or otherwise ensure you are not 
consulting the CrawlURI instance after its processing cycle has 
finished.

- Gordon @ IA
